Bill Bailey is a true Nebraska hero. I am honored to tell his story. #NEHeroes #ProudNebraskan
Bill was a wonderful husband, brother, son, father. He dedicated quite a bit of his life to helping other people. #NEHeroes
Specialist Bailey earned several military awards including the Purple Heart, Bronze Star, Iraqi Campaign Medal & Combat Action Badge. #Honor
More than one thousand people gathered in Bellevue to remember Bill. #NEHeroes
On May 25, 2007, during a security escort mission, Bill’s vehicle struck an improvised explosive device. Bill Bailey was killed. #NEHeroes
By 2007, the insurgency in Iraq had erupted to new levels of violence. Increased American forces sought to destroy the al Qaeda network.
In 2006, his unit was deployed and assigned to provide security escorts for truck convoys operating out of Balad Air Base in #Iraq.
That deep desire to serve the country continued to tug at him. In 2005, Bill re-enlisted in the @NENationalGuard #Courage
Bill’s protective nature made him a great father. It also made him a great firefighter. #NeHeroes
After 9/11, Bill felt the call to serve his country again. But, first things first. Bill and Dee married in 2004.
In December 2000, Bill met Dee. She was a bank teller at Wells Fargo; he drove an armored truck. They met through a service window.
Bill attended Bellevue East where the call to protect his country prompted him to enlist in the @NENationalGuard in 1995.

Importantly for employers, the #WorkplaceAdvancementAct wouldn't impose new federal regulations or mandates
With this flexibility, women can better negotiate arrangements that make sense for them. #Flexibility
When employees, especially women, have more information, they can confidently pursue favorable work and wage arrangements #KnowledgeIsPower
A culture of silence and fear of retaliation can keep people in the dark about how their wages compare to others’ #KnowledgeIsPower

He is a true Nebraska hero, and I am honored to tell his story. #SergeantGermaineDebro #NEHeroes
His military decorations include a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. #Courage
Germaine Debro was promoted posthumously to the rank of sergeant. #NEheroes
On September 18, 2006, the Morning Star Baptist Church near downtown Omaha was filled with people paying a final tribute to Sgt. Debro.
Sergeant Josiah Warren, riding in the right seat, tried unsuccessfully to pull Germaine free. Sgt. Debro died on 9/4/06
Thirty miles outside Baghdad, Germaine’s Humvee struck an improvised explosive device.
On September 4, 2006, a 20-truck convoy headed out from a site 30 miles north of Baghdad.
Germaine’s unit was right in the thick of it. Enemy attacks were frequent. Tensions were high.
After a year of training, the First of the 167th Cavalry arrived in Iraq in early 2006. That’s when the Sunni-Shia civil war erupted.
In 2005, Germaine learned his unit, the First of the 167th Cavalry of the @NEnationalGuard, would deploy to Iraq.
Germaine deployed to Kuwait in 2001 and to Bosnia in 2002. #ProudNebraskan #NEheroes
In 1994, “G.I. Joe Maine” followed his calling and enlisted in the #Army and in 1997 joined the @NEnationalguard
Germaine Debro seemed destined for military service. At a young age, he picked up a nick name: “G.I. Joe Maine.” #NEheroes

Cpt Yllescas of Osceola, NE is an American hero. It was my honor to tell his story on the Senate floor #NEheroes https://t.co/7gXno8h8GZ
Captain Robert Yllescas embodied the pride of his state, served his country, and loved his family. #ProudNebraskan
Ultimately, Rob’s severe leg and head wounds were too much to overcome. Captain Robert Yllescas died on Dec. 1, 2008.
During Rob’s time at Bethesda Naval Medical Center, President George W. Bush visited him & personally awarded him the #PurpleHeart.
Rob was quickly evacuated out of Afghanistan, stabilized, and moved to the Bethesda Naval Medical Center.
On October 28, 2008, a remotely-controlled IED was detonated and seriously wounded Captain Yllescas.
Rob achieved the rank of #Captain and deployed to Afghanistan in 2008 and stationed at Camp Keating, known to many as dangerous territory.
Returning home to #Nebraska in 2006, Rob continued to excel in the military, later graduating from Army Ranger School. #RangersLeadTheWay
He deployed to Iraq in 2003 for a year & then returned for a 2nd deployment in 2005, when the fighting grew more intense.
In 2001, Rob received his commission as a Second Lieutenant in the @USArmy. #ArmyStrong
At @UNLincoln, he fell in love with his wife Dena and they were married on July 29, 2000.
Rob enrolled in the @NENationalGuard while in college at @UNLincoln with hopes of becoming a general one day. #NEHeroes

Sergeant Joshua Robinson is a hero, and I am honored to tell his story. #NEheroes
https://t.co/1SnR3eGdzN
Nebraskans will remember Joshua Robinson for what he embodied and what it means to be one of “the few and the proud – a #Marine.”
Two months later, on August 7, 2011, Josh was out on patrol and shot twice by enemy combatants. He died shortly after.
He would later earn the Bronze Star for his actions that day. #ProudNebraskan #SemperFi
A few months later, on June 11, a fire fight broke out lasting six hours. During the attack, Josh rescued a wounded Marine. #Hero
After serving two tours in Iraq, he was deployed to Helmand Province, Afghanistan in March of 2011.
Josh’s fellow Marines say he was fearless. #SemperFi
By 2003, Josh had enlisted in the #Marine Corps. That year, he also met the love of his life, Rhonda Zaruba of Bennington, NE.
On 9/11, terrorist attacks on our homeland changed the world and instilled a deep sense of #duty and #patriotism for Josh.
Josh grew up on a farm near the small village of Oak, NE. He was born to be a #Marine.

Marine Corporal Adrian Robles is a hero and I am honored to tell his story. #SemperFi #NebraskaHeroes
Adrian embodied the strength and determination that #Nebraskans are known for all over the world.
Adrian’s mother, Yolanda, recalls that his life’s passion was to serve his country. #Patriotism #SemperFi
Corporal Robles was killed instantly. His unit was scheduled to leave Afghanistan two months later. #NEHeroes #USMC
A few months later, on October 22, 2008, Adrian was on patrol when suddenly his vehicle was hit by an IED.
In the spring of 2008, Corporal Adrian Robles deployed to #Afghanistan as part of the 2nd Battalion, 1st Marine Division.
He graduated from Scottsbluff High School in May of 2005 & immediately enlisted in @USMC #Marines
The WWII stories of Adrian’s grandfather, Pedro, inspired Adrian to become a Marine. #USMC

Today I honored the life of fallen @OmahaPolice officer Kerrie Orozco on the Senate floor. Read more from @MortonOWH https://t.co/NJWJwreB30
Officer Kerrie Orozco represents the best of Nebraska and our nation. She will forever inspire us to #KerrieOn
I join all Nebraskans to celebrate the life and legacy of a truly great person, proud police officer, and beloved wife and mother.
This month marks the first anniversary of Kerrie’s death, but her memory and service to Omaha live on in all of our hearts. #KerrieOn
Kerrie was killed 1 day before she was scheduled to bring her daughter Olivia home from the hospital & begin her postponed maternity leave.
When her team arrived, the suspect opened fire and Kerrie was hit. Officer Orozco died shortly after.
On May 20, 2015, Officer Orozco was preparing to serve an arrest warrant as a member of the @OmahaPolice Metro Area Fugitive Task Force.
As an officer with the @OmahaPolice, Kerrie became active in the community she protected.
Officer Orozco had a natural instinct for leadership and service, which led her to join the police force in 2007.
Leadership and service were in Kerrie’s blood. Her aunt, Laurie McNeil, said Kerrie always wanted to be a cop. #SupportBlue

Watch my full tribute to Master Sergeant Linda Tarango-Griess of Sutton, Nebraska on the #SenateFloor today. https://t.co/qc8iiaHllJ
I hope all Nebraskans remember her as an example of what it means to serve our nation with bravery, compassion, and joy. #NEheroes
Master Sergeant Linda Tarango-Griess was the first woman to lose her life in combat while serving in the @NENationalGuard.
Linda and another soldier were killed. She was only two weeks from returning to Nebraska. #NEHeroes
The convoy was attacked by al Qaeda insurgents, & Linda’s vehicle took a direct hit from an IED.
On July 11, 2004, Linda was driving in a convoy through a “high-threat” area in Samarra, Iraq.
In February of 2004, Linda deployed with the 267th Ordinance Company, arriving at Camp Speicher near Tikrit, Iraq.
Through the @NationalGuard, Linda discovered her passion for being a soldier in the U.S. military.
Linda’s willingness to serve as a role model and mentor for others came as no surprise to those who knew her.

or grandparents concerned about the future we will leave our grandchildren, there is no shortage of anxiety.
Whether it’s hardworking parents trying to make ends meet
I know many families across our state and across our nation are worried.
and creating flexible options for working families remain at the forefront of my priorities.
Building a stronger Nebraska, giving Americans more opportunities and more certainty…

to funding our military and passing policies to help prevent suicide among our veterans, we acted on the will of the American people.
From enacting a multi-year highway bill and reforming our education system...

Mr. President, what is your top priority? Mine is providing for the natl defense. #SignIt
It’s time for #POTUS to make #NDAA his top priority.
The federal government has no higher obligation than protecting our nation & providing for our national security.
Instead, he vetoed the NDAA based on a partisan, political demand to spend taxpayer dollars on the EPA & IRS.
#POTUS’ objections have nothing to do with our national security.
Our military needs the authorities contained in this bill to perform its missions & defend our nation.
As we have seen from the ever-growing list of global threats, these dangers are only increasing.
This year’s #NDAA is a #bipartisan compromise that meets the budgetary levels requested by #POTUS
It’s disappointing to see our commander in chief playing political games at the expense of our military.
